results.title: My childhood. My ain folk
results.creator_credit: BFI, Geoffrey Evans, Nick Nascht and Bill Douglas
results.brief_description: These first two instalments of the autobiographical “Trilogy” which was to be completed with “My way home” (1978) comprise an achievement unique in British cinema. The events experienced in the films by Jamie closely parallel those lived through by Douglas himself but his approach is impressionistic. The mystification this creates is all of a piece with the films’ effect; communication is a commodity which (like language itself) is in short supply in Jamie’s life. The meaning resides more fully in the visual structure. Tragic as the films are it is the ultimate victory of the imagination over circumstances that “My way home” will subsequently explore.

results.title: My brother Wartovo
results.creator_credit: Kestrel Film Productions and John Richardson
results.brief_description: John Wartovo lives in a small village in Nanuk, near Rabaul, Papua New Guinea. He does not own land there, and being aware of his responsibilities as a father, he applies for land in New Britain. This film deals with events leading up to his departure from his village and explores his doubts and problems. Music by Bruce Smeaton. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: My brother Tom
results.creator_credit: Crawford Productions, Rod Hardy and Pino Amenta
results.brief_description: St. Helen, 1938. A town divided by bigotry and charged emotions. World War II is raging in Europe, but all is peaceful in the small town of St. Helen. Days are unaffected by the fighting until a tragedy brings the reality of war to the town’s doorstep, a tragedy that shatters the entire community. At the same time, a love blossoms amidst age-old religious conflict. Adapted from the novel by James Aldridge.

results.title: My brother Jack
results.creator_credit: Country Education Project and Daryl Wayland
results.brief_description: Part one: Presents an interview with Jack Johnston’s wife and daughter to provide a background to the novel “My brother Jack”. Part Two: Features John Barnes of La Trobe University discussing the main issues raised in the book.

results.title: My Brilliant Career
results.creator_credit: New South Wales Film Corporation, Margaret Fink and Gillian Armstrong
results.brief_description: Based on the novel, “My Brilliant Career” by Miles Franklin, this is the story of Sybella Melvyn, a sensitive, passionate young woman who leaves the countryside in search of an artistic future. She develops a relationship with landowner Harry Beecham, but is faced with making a decision between less-than-perfect love and independence. Starring Judy Davis and Sam Neill.
results.creator_credit_for_label: New South Wales Film Corporation, Margaret Fink and Gillian Armstrong

results.title: My Boyfriend Came Back from the War
results.brief_description: My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is a browser-based internet artwork created in 1996 by Russian artist Olia Lialina and is an example of interactive hypertext storytelling.

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

results.title_for_label: My Boyfriend Came Back from the War
results.description:
My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is a browser-based internet artwork created in 1996 by Russian artist Olia Lialina.

My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is an example of interactive hypertext storytelling. The work consists of nested frames with black and white web pages and (sometimes animated) grainy GIF images. When clicking hyperlinks in the work, the frame splits into smaller frames and the user reveals a nonlinear story about a couple that is reunited after a nameless military conflict. The lovers find it difficult to reconnect; the woman confesses that she has had an affair with a neighbour while the returned soldier proposes marriage. The story unfolds to the point where the screen has become a mosaic of empty black frames.

Olia Lialina calls the work a netfilm, because of its similarity with cinematic narrative. The grainy black-and-white images and intertitles refer to early silent movies. Of its filmic qualities, curator Michael Connor wrote of the work, “the work adapts cinematic montage to the web … separate frames are joined together by HTML code and the browser itself and experienced in both space and in time, employing what Lev Manovich has characterized as spatial and temporal montage.” - Wikipedia
description_for_label:
My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is a browser-based internet artwork created in 1996 by Russian artist Olia Lialina.

My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is an example of interactive hypertext storytelling. The work consists of nested frames with black and white web pages and (sometimes animated) grainy GIF images. When clicking hyperlinks in the work, the frame splits into smaller frames and the user reveals a nonlinear story about a couple that is reunited after a nameless military conflict. The lovers find it difficult to reconnect; the woman confesses that she has had an affair with a neighbour while the returned soldier proposes marriage. The story unfolds to the point where the screen has become a mosaic of empty black frames.

Olia Lialina calls the work a netfilm, because of its similarity with cinematic narrative. The grainy black-and-white images and intertitles refer to early silent movies. Of its filmic qualities, curator Michael Connor wrote of the work, “the work adapts cinematic montage to the web … separate frames are joined together by HTML code and the browser itself and experienced in both space and in time, employing what Lev Manovich has characterized as spatial and temporal montage.” - Wikipedia

results.title: My Body
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PGR Series”.
This title covers the following topics: Circumcision - we provide information about why and how this operation is performed on male babies, and discuss the care of the uncircumcised penis. Teeth - the symptoms and some solutions to teething problems are discussed and PGR looks at how to keep teeth healthy. Feet and Legs - children often appear to have bandy legs, knock knees or pigeon toes in early years of walking. An orthopaedic surgeon discusses these in the context of the development of a “normal” walking pattern. Body Awareness - PGR discusses children’s body awareness illustrating the way in which children discover and play with their bodies. Questions - groups of parents talk about how best to answer those awkward or embarrassing questions children ask about their bodies.
